com.kontakt.sdk.android.model

Class Beacon

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.kontakt.sdk.android.model.Device
      • com.kontakt.sdk.android.model.Beacon
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Parcelable, com.kontakt.sdk.core.interfaces.model.IBeacon<ContentAction,BrowserAction,Venue>, com.kontakt.sdk.core.interfaces.model.IDevice<ContentAction,BrowserAction,Venue>

    public class Beacon
extends Device
implements com.kontakt.sdk.core.interfaces.model.IBeacon<ContentAction,BrowserAction,Venue>
    Beacon model represents JSON model of Beacon device with kontakt.io logic applied. Beacon is a property of a Manager (Manager). It acts also as a container for Actions and may be assigned to certain Venue (Venue). Beacon is obtainable via REST Client. Please, note that there is also Beacon class representing real Beacon device that appears immediately once it is detected by Android Device' BluetoothAdapter (BluetoothAdapter). By convention this model is fully immutable. To create new instance of the model, please use the Beacon.Builder.

    • Field Detail

      • CREATOR

        public static final Parcelable.Creator<Beacon> CREATOR
        Parcelable CREATOR constant. This model may be put into Bundle once you decide to save its state. However, please be aware of some limitations.
        • There may be situations in which parent object may contain a member holding reference to the parent object in its member. Once such object is parceled, every child will be recreated with its member set to null. This limitation prevents from infinite parceling recursion causing StackOverflowError
        • Every model that contains FileData as its member will be recreated with this member set to null. Please organise the access to the data in different way.
        For more information concerning parceling see attached links.
        See Also:
        Android SDK documentation - Parcelable, Android SDK documentation - Activity.onSaveInstanceState(android.os.Bundle) method, Android SDK documentation - Bundle

      • databaseId

        protected final int databaseId
        The Database id. The database Id was introduced once you decide to persist your model in local storage (e.g. SQLiteDatabase). If you do not need to use it, ignore it during model building.
